These origins are not so ancient as to be beyond our knowledge, nor do they disappear, like the sources of the <tei-placeName ref="#Nil" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Nile</tei-placeName>, into the mountains and clouds. The buccaneers, privateers, and other no less remarkable characters who settled in <tei-placeName ref="#StD" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Domingue</tei-placeName> and the <tei-placeName ref="#ANTE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Antilles</tei-placeName> about 200 years ago are the noble ancestors of the colonial aristocracy. Undoubtedly, as the poet says:</tei-p>

<tei-quote data-origname="quote">One does not choose one's father.</tei-quote>

<tei-p data-origname="p">But in that case, one should at least refrain from casting stones at others and, as much as possible, avoid looking down on anyone.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">This debate was proceeding peacefully when it attracted a formidable adversary to Mr. Bissette: Mr. <tei-persName ref="#CIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Cicéron</tei-persName>, a lawyer from Martinique. This gentleman, after extensively discussing the new organic law of the colonies in a rather substantial pamphlet, condescended to come down from his lofty heights and temper the severity of the subject with notes filled with wit, in which he liberally sprinkled, in place of humor and jovial remarks, insults and defamation. Here are a few examples:</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Decidedly and at all costs, Mr. Bissette wants to be</tei-emph> NOTICED!</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Finally, Mr. Bissette, whom we accidentally caught by the tail while flipping through his treatise, as if we were handling a venomous creature, etc...</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">But look how far the naïve malice of Mr. Bissette goes! <tei-emph data-origname="emph">He is a mulatto, he is illegitimate</tei-emph>; by these qualities, he shares with us the descent of vagabonds; and yet that does not stop him <tei-pb facs="v1n5f24" n="24" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> from speaking his mind… Shame! The nasty bird that soils its own nest!... the nest where the Black woman, mother or grandmother of Mr. Bissette, laid the precious egg that was fertilized by the most libertine and depraved, no doubt, of the highway robbers he speaks of!... And might he not even have an advantage over us in this respect?… that of descending, perhaps, all by himself, from all the vagabonds put together!…</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Provoked in such a brutal manner, Mr. Bissette owed Mr. Cicéron a few words in reply, and he did so on <tei-date when="1833-05-15" data-origname="date" data-origatts="when">May 15, 1833</tei-date>:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">His <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Letter to Mr. Cicéron</tei-emph> had been in circulation for more than a year without any complaint. A new edition was printed in July of this year, and suddenly Mr. Artaud, apparently the uncle of Mr. Cicéron, claimed to be defamed in this publication and summoned Mr. Bissette before the sixth chamber of the court of first instance in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Thus, on August 5, Mr. Artaud, through his attorney <tei-persName ref="#Be" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Bethmont</tei-persName>, came to seek redress for the slander he claimed to have suffered, demanding in addition the suppression and seizure, wherever found, of the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Letter by Mr. Bissette</tei-emph>, as well as the posting of the judgment in Paris and Martinique, in an unspecified number of thousands of copies.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Bethmont then took the floor and, after a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Ciceronian</tei-emph> exordium, launched into a long, well-structured, and highly dramatic eulogy of his client. His grandiloquent tone, his emphatic and tearful delivery, and his glowing rhetoric are but part of his attributes. His passion often carries over into his gestures and oratory; he writhes, drowns himself in incredible melancholies, sways like a reed in the wind, or rather like a palm tree shaken by the hurricane of the Antilles; then, majestically hovering above the bench, he addresses the court, the public prosecutor, Mr. Bissette, his opponent, the audience, everyone and everything. Always with the same elegance, he attacks Mr. Bissette violently; after his grandiloquent outburst, he quotes the following passage from Mr. Bissette’s letter to Mr. Cicéron:</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">That is truly splendid defamation, admit it. How courageous you are against me, Master Cicéron, when eighteen hundred leagues separate us! But, in the absence of other means to confront you in person, I challenge you to prove that a single charge of immorality could be leveled against my honorable mother. Ah! Sir, I would not fear a public appeal to the opinion of our country regarding my mother, even though you seek to reproach me for her skin color. If the shade of one’s skin is a measure of virtue, then bow before her memory! <tei-pb facs="v1n5f25" n="25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> For it was not she, mulatto though she was, who presented to society the scandalous example of a wife living in disgraceful concubinage with her brother, offering all the spectacle of immoral incestuous relations; raising the offspring of her <tei-emph data-origname="emph">precious egg</tei-emph> in the habit of insult and slander; turning her accomplice’s establishment into the public theater of her disorder, and carrying her cynicism so far as to defy the opinion, the memories, and the gaze of society! I do not ask you, sir, to respect the memory and ashes of the dead… that is a virtue still unknown to you, but I do urge you, in your own interest, to tread carefully with the blood that runs twice in your veins.</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Bethmont read this passage with a superb expression of pain and indignation, which does great credit to his sensitivity. He attempted to demonstrate that there was indeed defamation against Mr. Artaud, even though his name did not appear in the incriminated passage; he relied on a note on the following page to prove that there could be no doubt about the individuals concerned. Finally, in a rather peculiar move that no one had requested, Mr. Bethmont presented several documents and certificates of notoriety to demonstrate, according to him, the absolute and material impossibility of the immorality charge against Mr. Artaud.</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">Mstr. <tei-persName ref="#JM" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">JULES MAUREL</tei-persName>, speaking on behalf of Mr. Bissette, declared that his client had never harbored the intent to defame Mr. Artaud; that he knew him not, nor bore him any animosity; but that Mr. Bissette, unjustly provoked by Mr. Cicéron—provoked in the most violent manner—had merely responded to such a challenge under the impulse of just indignation. As for the allegations that Mr. Artaud claims to be directed against him, they contain no specific mention of persons, and thus, it is Mr. Artaud himself who has assumed their application and, in so doing, defamed his own name.</tei-p><tei-pb facs="v1n5f26" n="26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Following the replies of both attorneys and the conclusions of the public prosecutor—who deferred to the wisdom of the tribunal—Mr. Bissette rose and addressed the court in these words:</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Gentlemen, placing my trust in your discernment to adopt the just conclusions presented by my advocate, I nevertheless feel bound to add a few words, that the moral import of this case may be the better understood.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Men of color in the colonies, as you well know, gentlemen, have long suffered the yoke of oppression under the dominion of the white colonists. The abuse of power and a judicial system perverted by exceptional privileges have weighed heavily upon them. Among the many victims of this cruel colonial order, I bear an indelible mark—a testimony to the depths of iniquity that caste prejudice may descend to in those distant lands. Yes, gentlemen, I WAS BRANDED—branded for the mere act of reading a pamphlet, and for sharing it with two of my brethren. And it is this very BRAND that stirred the righteous indignation of <tei-placeName ref="#EUR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Europe</tei-placeName> against that magistrate who, with unholy eagerness, hastened to have the executioner imprint it upon my flesh, though a legal appeal was yet pending—an appeal that, in the hands of impartial judges, would assuredly have wrought an emphatic reversal. This BRAND, which some would make an ignominious reproach against me, I hold rather as a badge of honor—a symbol of my sufferings, my cause, and my convictions. You know, gentlemen, what this reproach has inspired in me. When confronted with an adversary so wholly devoid of noble <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">sentimens</tei-orig><tei-reg data-origname="reg">sentiments</tei-reg></tei-choice>, and who, as a white colonist, deemed himself entitled to all liberties against a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">mulatto</tei-emph>—stooping, as he did, to heap the foulest calumny upon me and mine—I deemed it best not to seek redress through the courts, as I am brought before you today. Rather, I took up my pen and wrote the <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Letter to Mstr. Cicéron</tei-bibl>, in which, after fifteen months of silence, Mr. Artaud has suddenly chosen to discern an offense, a crime of defamation, against himself.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I shall say but one thing more.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">That letter, gentlemen, was addressed solely and explicitly to Mstr. Cicéron. If he considers himself aggrieved, let him come forward—let him make his complaint after fifteen months<tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">.</tei-sic><tei-reg data-origname="reg">,</tei-reg></tei-choice> let him summon me before this tribunal! It is to him, and to him alone, that I shall respond. As for Mr. Artaud, he stands in no way concerned in this matter, and I know not what claim he seeks to advance. I shall not, in any manner, enter into the discussion of his grievance. To my eyes, this pretense of defamation is naught but a veiled attempt at caste vengeance, and Mr. Artaud will find that I do not consider his accusations worthy of reply.</tei-p><tei-pb facs="v1n5f27" n="27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Unfortunate indeed is the man of color when he must contend with the justice of the dominant caste in the colonies—a caste to which Mr. Artaud belongs! Yet those who have pursued me with their malice there, now hope that I shall meet the same fate before the impartial judges of Europe. In those miserable colonies, gentlemen, there are men who, for lesser words than those I have written, would have been <tei-emph data-origname="emph">hanged and strangled until death ensued</tei-emph>, at the decree of men like Mr. Artaud. Such men flatter themselves with the expectation that they shall find here a tribunal as ready to condemn a <tei-emph data-origname="emph">mulatto insolent enough to contradict a white man</tei-emph>, as the court of Martinique once did. Yet they forget that before your enlightened judgment, such a qualification, which they would make my crime, and the recollection of the blows they have dealt me, would serve, were I indeed guilty, not as an argument for my condemnation, but rather as a title to your indulgence.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">But such apprehension is foreign to my mind, for before judges such as you, gentlemen, and in a case such as this, I cannot but have full confidence in the outcome. Indeed, had I chosen to remain silent, I could well have left the full weight of my defense in the able hands of my counsel. But the few words I have spoken, I trust, may cast additional light upon the moral truths at the heart of this trial.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Gentlemen, in closing the letter which has become the subject of this prosecution, I wrote to my adversary that <tei-emph data-origname="emph">it was impossible that, in a cause of pure morality and reason, the white men of Martinique would acknowledge him as their representative</tei-emph>. And today, I declare with even greater assurance: it is unthinkable that the advocates of the French Bar should acknowledge as their colleague a man who has so far forgotten the dignity of his station as to put into writing these words:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">..... The nest where the Black woman, mother or grandmother of Mr. Bissette, laid the precious egg, fertilized, no doubt, by the most libertine and depraved of highwaymen!..... And indeed, has he not an advantage over us in this?..... That he alone, perhaps, descends from all the vagabonds together!</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I have spoken.</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The tribunal, after a lengthy deliberation, applying to Mr. Bissette the provisions of Articles 15 and 18 of the law of <tei-date when="1819-05-17" data-origname="date" data-origatts="when">May 17, 1819</tei-date>, yet acknowledging in his favor numerous extenuating circumstances, has sentenced him only to a fine of twenty-five francs, declining to order the destruction of the document or the public posting of the judgment, as had been so insistently demanded by the prosecution.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mstr. BETHMONT. – I readily concede the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">extenuating circumstances</tei-emph><tei-pb facs="v1n5f28" n="28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> in favor of Mr. Bissette, for they arise from the gross provocation under which he wrote; but as these do not negate the falsity of the accusations made, I desire that the judgment be amended to state: <tei-emph data-origname="emph">“but independent of that which concerns Mr. Artaud.”</tei-emph></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">MR. PRESIDENT. – The tribunal has <tei-emph data-origname="emph">deliberated at length</tei-emph> upon this matter; yet, though it considers your arguments, it cannot alter its ruling.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mstr. Bethmont, with great fervor, persisted in urging the tribunal to modify the wording of its judgment. The president, in reply, declared that the tribunal, in drafting its decision as it had, had sought to make explicit its favorable view of Mr. Bissette’s position, in light of the provocation he had suffered.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Bissette bowed before the tribunal and withdrew, leaving Mstr. Bethmont to gesticulate and expostulate before a crowded audience.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Among those who gathered to offer Mr. Bissette their congratulations were men of letters, journalists, and a considerable number of men of color from many lands. Meanwhile, Mstr. Bethmont continued to harangue the court, though the usher had already called forth another case.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="civil-tribunal" id="civil-tribunal" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">CIVIL TRIBUNAL OF THE SEINE (Chamber of Vacations)</tei-head>
<tei-head data-origname="head">PRESIDED OVER BY M. FOUQUET.</tei-head>
<tei-head data-origname="head">CASE OF <tei-persName ref="#BOI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">BOITEL</tei-persName> VERSUS <tei-persName ref="#CIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">CICÉRON</tei-persName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Having failed in both the Correctional Police Court and the Royal Court in his complaint concerning a certain publication against him by Sieur <tei-persName ref="#CIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Cicéron</tei-persName>, an attorney at <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, Mr. Boitel, former secretary-archivist of that colony, who had before the lower courts suffered the effects of an interpretative ruling invoking the statute of limitations, sought, as a last resort, to bring his case before the Civil Tribunal of the Seine. Through the representation of Mstr. <tei-persName ref="#RAB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Rabou</tei-persName>, his attorney, he invoked the provisions of Article 42 of the law of May 26, 1819, which stipulates that, in all cases, a legal action undertaken at the request of the plaintiff may be brought before the courts of his domicile, provided that the publication in question has occurred there. He stated that there was no dispute that said publication had indeed taken place in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>, the place of residence of Mr. Boitel.<tei-pb facs="v1n5f29" n="29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> Thus, by seizing jurisdiction of the Civil Tribunal of the Seine, he had properly submitted his case before the judges of his domicile.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mstr. <tei-persName ref="#MORE" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">MORET</tei-persName>, attorney for Sieur Cicéron, contended that Mr. Boitel was bound to plead his case in Martinique; that his client could not be deprived of his natural judges; and that it fell within the jurisdiction of that colonial tribunal, where the accused resided, to determine the merits of the case.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mstr. RABOU, in response, argued that Mr. Boitel had been expelled from the colony in <tei-date data-origname="date">1831</tei-date> by a resolution of the Privy Council of Martinique, for the crime of having received men of color at his table. He asserted that the publication against which Mr. Boitel now complained was but one of many <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">incidens</tei-orig><tei-reg data-origname="reg">incidents</tei-reg></tei-choice> which had arisen as a result of his unwavering stand for justice and his open declaration of principles in favor of the colored population and the enslaved.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. <tei-persName ref="#POI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">POINSOT</tei-persName>, advocate for the King, impartially analyzed the arguments put forth by both parties and, relying on the plain text of the law, concluded by recommending that the court uphold the claims of the plaintiff and reject the defendant’s objections.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The following judgment was rendered on October 29, after hearing both the parties and the public prosecutor:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Considering the explicit provisions of the law of May 26, 1829, the tribunal declares itself competent to hear the case and retains it for adjudication after the vacation period. It condemns Mr. Cicéron to bear the costs.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="bissette-cicéron" id="bissette-cicéron" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">ENCOUNTER BETWEEN BISSETTE AND CICÉRON.</tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Having been grossly offended by a pamphlet published by <tei-persName ref="#CIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Cicéron</tei-persName>, an attorney at Martinique, Mr. Bissette had, in a printed letter responding to that pamphlet, expressed deep regret that he was unable to exact immediate satisfaction.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Eighteen months later, Mr. Cicéron saw fit to travel eighteen hundred leagues, as he was fond of repeating, for the sole purpose of placing himself at Mr. Bissette’s disposal; which he did. <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Bissette</tei-persName> thereupon issued his challenge, and a duel with sabers ensued in the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Bois de Vincennes</tei-placeName>, during which Mr. Cicéron was wounded in the right arm,<tei-pb facs="v1n5f30" n="30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> rendering him incapable of further use of the limb. Upon this, the adversaries and their witnesses parted ways.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Some time afterward, having recovered from his injury, Mr. Cicéron, prompted by reasons which we shall not presume to judge, dispatched two of his witnesses to Mr. Bissette, requesting that the combat be resumed. This request may have suited Mr. Cicéron’s interests, but Mr. Bissette had no obligation to gratify him. Accordingly, Mr. Bissette firmly rejected the colonial lawyer’s demand, declaring to these gentlemen that, having already rendered Mr. Cicéron unfit for combat, he was entirely satisfied with the result and was determined to pursue the matter no further.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Upon receiving this response, Mr. Cicéron deemed it necessary to appeal to public opinion. A correspondence was thus initiated between these two gentlemen in the only newspaper of the capital that had granted Mr. Cicéron its columns. Mr. Bissette, however, steadfastly maintained in writing the same position he had previously stated in person—that in matters of honor, all had been conducted as befitted men of heart and dignity, and that none but himself had the right to judge whether he was satisfied, seeing that he himself declared it so.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Here follows the letter published in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#Fig" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Figaro</tei-title></tei-bibl> on October 11, by which Mr. Bissette put an end to the strange pretensions of his adversary:</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">To the Editor of the Figaro</tei-emph>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Paris, <tei-date when="1834-10-10" data-origname="date" data-origatts="when">October 10, 1834</tei-date>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Sir,</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">One final word regarding the latest letter from Mr. Cicéron, published in today’s issue of your paper: it shall be my last.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I shall not here undertake to expose the numerous contradictions between Mr. Cicéron’s first letter and his second. That question, as far as I am concerned, is settled. Whatever his future claims or declarations on this matter may be, they shall be to me as though they never were. I am resolved, sir, to leave entirely to him the field which you have so generously offered us, should he still desire to appear upon it.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I state it once again: I shall not pursue this matter further, on<tei-pb facs="v1n5f31" n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> any ground whatsoever, save only that of legitimate self-defense, should circumstances demand it. Whether Mr. Cicéron is my adversary or my enemy, I know not which.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">In all else, I refer to my previous written and spoken replies. And though I do not presume that the public is a competent judge in a matter so personal as this, where the claims of both sides cannot always be taken at face value, I see no reason why I should not leave it to them to judge this dispute, however difficult it may be to furnish them with all the facts.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Accept, sir, etc.  
BISSETTE.</tei-p></tei-q>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The editor of this publication would not have troubled the public with an affair so purely personal, had it not been Mr. Cicéron himself who first invoked the press in an attempt to give it notoriety. It may be observed, moreover, that in the latest issue of the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Revue des Colonies</tei-bibl>, no mention was made of the duel in which Mr. Cicéron was wounded, so unimportant did Mr. Bissette deem the matter to his readers.</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="miscellaneous-news" id="miscellaneous-news" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Moniteur</tei-bibl> publishes the following ordinance, dated October 29:</tei-p>

<tei-quote data-origname="quote"><tei-p data-origname="p">"The resignation tendered by M. <tei-persName ref="#EMG" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Marshal Gérard</tei-persName>, President of the Council and Minister Secretary of State for the Department of War, is accepted.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The interim administration of the War Ministry shall be entrusted to <tei-persName ref="#HR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. de Rigny</tei-persName>, Minister of Foreign Affairs."</tei-p></tei-quote>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- M. <tei-persName ref="#JDI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Joseph Duton-Inginac</tei-persName>, captain and aide-de-camp to the Haitian General <tei-persName ref="#JBI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Inginac</tei-persName>, his father, and secretary to the cabinet of President <tei-persName ref="#JPB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Boyer</tei-persName>, has unexpectedly passed away at <tei-placeName ref="#Hav" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Le Havre</tei-placeName>, just as he was preparing to return to his homeland. M. Duton-Inginac was but twenty years of age. We had seen him, on the very day of his departure from Paris, full of health and vigor. His premature death shall be a cause of deep sorrow and mourning, not only for his family but also for his country. The Haitian Republic had placed its highest hopes upon this honorable citizen. His remains, currently resting at Le Havre in the <tei-placeName ref="#CSR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Roch Chapel</tei-placeName>, shall soon be <tei-pb facs="v1n5f32" n="32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> transported to <tei-placeName ref="#HT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Haiti</tei-placeName>, a feeble consolation for his grieving family, who had never foreseen that they would see him again only as a lifeless form.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- A foundation stone has recently been laid in <tei-placeName ref="#Lo" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">London</tei-placeName> for an edifice erected in memory of the abolition of colonial slavery. The selected site is in Fischer Street, <tei-placeName ref="#RLS" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Red Lion Square</tei-placeName>. The lower floor shall serve as a Sunday school and a regular school for children of both sexes, while the upper floor will house twelve <tei-emph data-origname="emph">alms-rooms</tei-emph>. The institution is affiliated with the Baptist church and congregation of Eagle Street, under the ministry of MM. J. <tei-persName ref="#JI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ivimey</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#Ov" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Overbury</tei-persName>. A large assembly gathered in the temple, where, after the singing of hymns by <tei-persName ref="#IW" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Watts</tei-persName>, the Reverend <tei-persName ref="#FP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">F. Price</tei-persName>, of Devonshire Square, commenced the solemnity by reading <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Psalm 126</tei-bibl> and offering a prayer of thanksgiving. The Reverend J. Ivimey then introduced the Reverend <tei-persName ref="#WK" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">W. Knibb</tei-persName>, who has traveled extensively and made extraordinary efforts for the cause of liberty among the poor Negroes, covering, in these pilgrimages of charity, more than nine hundred miles. Following the discourse of this zealous missionary, the procession formed and proceeded to the site; there, the session’s president, <tei-persName ref="#MHP" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. H. Pownal</tei-persName>, in a lively and compelling address, traced the history of efforts toward the abolition of the slave trade from its introduction by the Spaniards in <tei-date data-origname="date">1503</tei-date> to the endeavors of <tei-persName ref="#TCL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Clarkson</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#WW" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Wilberforce</tei-persName>. Then, a man of color, M. <tei-persName ref="#RSm" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Robert Smith</tei-persName>, was presented before the vast assembly; he shattered an iron slave chain and one of those dreadful cartwhips, the customary instrument of suffering for the unfortunate blacks. These melancholy <tei-emph data-origname="emph">monuments</tei-emph> of a scourge now ending were placed within a cavity of the foundation stone, while the assembly intoned the following hymn:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">
Unfortunate children of Africa’s shores,  
Behold these fragments of your last chains;  
Join your free voices to our sacred hymns,  
And bless the Lord who has delivered you.
</tei-q></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The stone was then sealed by the architect. When completed, the edifice shall present a noble façade, and an inscription above its main entrance shall commemorate the great event which a benevolent charity has thus sought to immortalize.</tei-p><tei-pb facs="v1n5f33" n="33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- In <tei-placeName ref="#ANG" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">England</tei-placeName>, a medal has been struck in commemoration of the abolition of Negro slavery. It would be impossible to conceive of a more ingenious and striking representation, simultaneously depicting both the horrid condition of negroes in their state of bondage and the profound emotions they experience upon, at last, treading underfoot the instruments of their torture and raising their eyes heavenward in devout gratitude. The obverse of this medal portrays a Negro gazing at the sun, arms outstretched, holding a broken chain; beneath his feet lies the murderous whip, its blood-stained lashes torn from the shattered handle. The legend reads: <tei-quote data-origname="quote"> "This was the Lord’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes. Psalm CXVIII, v. 25. – <tei-date when="1834-08-01" data-origname="date" data-origatts="when">August 1, 1834</tei-date>."</tei-quote> The reverse bears the inscription: <tei-quote data-origname="quote">"In commemoration of the abolition of slavery in the colonial possessions of Great Britain, under the reign of <tei-persName ref="#GIV" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">William IV</tei-persName>." (The Semeur.)"</tei-quote></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- We are pleased to report an act of rare generosity, one that does honor to humanity, by the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">British and Foreign Bible Society</tei-emph>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">This Society has just voted the sum of 20,000 pounds sterling (500,000 francs) to contribute to the religious education of the negroes. A copy of the <tei-bibl type="monogr" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">New Testament</tei-bibl> and a collection of psalms will be distributed to all emancipated slaves who can read as of <tei-date data-origname="date">August 1854</tei-date>. Those lacking this initial knowledge shall not, however, be deprived of the same benefit, provided they are heads of families with children who can read or are learning to do so.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">With a similarly laudable intent, the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Society for the Distribution of Religious Publications</tei-emph> (<tei-emph data-origname="emph">The Religious Tracts Society</tei-emph>) had, last year, allocated 400 pounds sterling (10,000 francs) for various books intended to form small libraries for the use of negroes. We now learn that this philanthropic society has recently resolved to distribute numerous additional publications throughout the English colonies, wherein the freed blacks may acquire the knowledge befitting their newfound condition.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- Letters from <tei-placeName ref="#BAR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Barbados</tei-placeName>, dated September 10, announce that the most perfect tranquility reigns in that colony and the neighboring islands, including <tei-placeName ref="#StC" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint Christopher</tei-placeName>, where disturbances had been feared. <tei-placeName ref="#BER" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Berbice</tei-placeName> was also in a satisfactory state as of September 1.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- <tei-persName ref="#SC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. de Scholten</tei-persName>, governor of the Danish possessions in the <tei-placeName ref="#InO" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">West Indies</tei-placeName>, has presented to the government of <tei-placeName ref="#DAN" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Denmark</tei-placeName> a most extensive memorandum concerning the measures to be adopted for effecting the complete emancipation of the blacks still held in bondage therein. A commission was immediately appointed to examine the governor's plan and to issue, with all possible haste, its report, so that M. de Scholten, before his departure for the colony of <tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Thomas</tei-placeName>, the seat of his government, might receive the necessary instructions, or at the very least, that the principles by which he is to be guided may be firmly established.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- The papers of <tei-placeName ref="#NY" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">New York</tei-placeName> announce that on September 24, during the occasion of a balloon ascension, several Negroes were maltreated and forced to flee from the unprovoked fury of the whites. The newspapers denounce such barbarous acts with great indignation.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- The journals of <tei-placeName ref="#CARA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Caracas</tei-placeName> report a dreadful catastrophe that is said to have nearly annihilated the <tei-placeName ref="#StMa" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">island of Santa Marta</tei-placeName>. In the last days of May, an appalling volcanic eruption, preceded and followed by forty-five shocks of a terrible earthquake, is alleged to have engulfed part of the city. Nearly all the buildings, both great and small, are reported to have been reduced to ruins. Only a few casualties are noted, as the entire population had time to seek refuge in the wooded highlands. Scarcely a handful of houses remain standing amidst the wreckage.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">This island now presents nothing but the most complete scene of desolation, and its unfortunate inhabitants can place their hopes only in the compassion they inspire and the benevolence of their neighbors.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Dupetit-Thouars</tei-persName>, a naval captain, has been entrusted with a mission from the government to the <tei-placeName ref="#HT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Republic of Haiti</tei-placeName>. This officer is set to assume command of the corvette <tei-emph data-origname="emph">La Créole</tei-emph>, already anchored in the roadstead of <tei-placeName ref="#BRE" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Brest</tei-placeName>. The brig <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Le Cuirassier</tei-emph> is also attached to this expedition.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- <tei-persName ref="#APe" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Auguste Périnon</tei-persName>, a man of color from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>,<tei-pb n="34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> having distinguished himself over two years at the École Polytechnique, has recently entered, at his own request, as an officer in the marine artillery. M. Périnon has obtained his rank through competitive examination. We announce this news with joy to our young compatriots of color. Let them, through honorable exertions and by demonstrating ability in all careers, dispel the unworthy prejudices of their oppressors.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Another laurel is to be added to the crown of <tei-persName ref="#ANog" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Arsène Nogues</tei-persName>. This attorney general has carried out, prior to any appeal for cassation or clemency, the execution of a ruling by the so-called assize court of Martinique, condemning two slaves to death for homicide. Guilty or not, it matters little to us: their appeal was a right. These condemned men were hanged and strangled until death ensued.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I have given an account, in the latest issue of the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type">Revue des Colonies</tei-bibl>, of a conversation I had with the former attorney general of Martinique, who branded me, in defiance of my appeal to the court of cassation.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">A circular letter, signed by <tei-persName ref="#RL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">De Lucy</tei-persName>, has just been published; the signatory declares <tei-emph data-origname="emph">that what he did, he was bound to do</tei-emph>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">I reproached the former attorney general for his conduct in hastening the execution of the ruling that condemned me, and for the ignoble act of wresting, through threats, from my wife a letter of solace that I had sent her as I descended from the scaffold, a letter which he read and then burned. These deeds, I have confronted him with them face to face; and he calls them <tei-emph data-origname="emph">duties fulfilled without passion, as without weakness!</tei-emph> Such is the character of this man; he fails to perceive that these are acts of infamy; he lacks even the awareness of his own atrocity and cowardice in <tei-date data-origname="date">1824</tei-date>. And yet, he dares to stand before a civilized people and proclaim, <tei-emph data-origname="emph">that what he did, he was bound to do</tei-emph>. Let there be scorn and execration upon this man! Execration and scorn!</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">BISSETTE</tei-persName></tei-p><tei-pb facs="v1n5f34" n="35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="french-colonies" id="french-colonies" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-head>
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">MARTINIQUE</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">We have received a letter from <tei-placeName ref="#StP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>, dated August 29:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">For some days now, a troupe of dramatic artists has arrived at Fort-Royal and has been offering performances twice a week. Would you believe that entrance to this spectacle is forbidden to men of color? Take note: this is not a private society. Twelve grenadiers of the 1st Marine Regiment are stationed around the theater hall to keep out Negroes and mulattoes. Such, my dear friend, is the outcome of the July Revolution in the colonies…</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">- Another letter from Fort-Royal, dated September 1, reports:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">There now exists here a theater, the proprietors of which, in order to exclude men of color, have devised the scheme of establishing a subscription-only society, open to whites alone. The advertisements are delivered to homes bearing this title: "THEATER BY PRIVATE SUBSCRIPTION." Military personnel, of whatever rank, are admitted, along with anyone who claims to be white. It must be noted that the governor has never attended, but neither has he made any effort to prevent such disgraceful practices; indeed, he tacitly condones them by his silence.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Yesterday, a solemn musical mass was held; it was likely in honor of <tei-persName ref="#HeV" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Henri V</tei-persName>, though disguised as a celebration of Saint Louis, the patron of the parish. The bourgeois musicians of the white class, who largely constituted the orchestra, took care to ensure that no men of color were present at the ceremony. The parish beadle was instructed to forcibly expel any who attempted to enter the church, and those who had already entered were thrown out. <tei-persName ref="#ND" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Nelson Didier</tei-persName>, a man of color, approached the priest after mass to complain of this treatment, only to receive a harsh and dismissive response, insulting his entire class. Among other things, the priest declared that he "cared nothing for the opinion of men of color, that he trampled them underfoot, and that their feelings were of no concern to him." After such an event, judge for yourself how fearfully the hatred of our enemies is advancing, when even the church—where all ranks, distinctions, and prejudices ought to be erased—is not exempt from such odious oppression.<tei-pb facs="v1n5f35" n="36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/></tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="guiana" id="guiana" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GUIANA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The letters we receive from <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName> all concur in praising the wise and just administration of <tei-persName ref="#Pa" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Parizet</tei-persName>, interim governor of French Guiana. It seems that no one mourns the departure of Governor <tei-persName ref="#Ju" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jubelin</tei-persName>.</tei-p>

<tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Our subscribers may perhaps appreciate the faithful portrait of this governor, which one of our correspondents has furnished. He writes as follows:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">“M. Jubelin has surrounded himself with a clique of favorites; he has found means to violate the law in order to appoint his own creatures. It is a strange and scandalous fact, yet undeniable, that every single officer of the judiciary, including the justice of the peace, belongs to his coterie. This very justice of the peace, in violation of all legal principles, simultaneously serves as the head of the militia. A devoted reactionary and an ardent Carlist, the mere sight of a tricolor flag fills him with horror.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Perhaps in <tei-placeName ref="#FR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">France</tei-placeName> one imagines that the laws declaring all citizens equally eligible for public office are enforced in this colony? This is a grave error.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Governor Jubelin has systematically excluded men of color from positions in the administration, under the false pretense that they do not meet the legal qualifications. Thus, men of integrity and ability are cast aside—solely because they are men of color. Yet, while M. Jubelin has applied the strictest interpretation of regulations to disqualify men of color, he has not been so scrupulous when appointing his white favorites.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">For instance, the young <tei-persName ref="#SQ" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Quantin</tei-persName> served as King’s Prosecutor despite not meeting the age requirement, never obtaining an age exemption, nor even taking the required oath. This violation of the law has caused great scandal and unrest in the colony. Similarly, <tei-persName ref="#Rev" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Revoil</tei-persName>, a former solicitor, was appointed judge-auditor, and within months was promoted to provisional counselor-auditor—a flagrant violation of the very laws and ordinances that explicitly exclude him from holding these positions, as M. Revoil does not even hold a degree in law.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">But M. Revoil belongs to the Jubelin-Gibelin-Vidal triumvirate, and he has the honor of playing reversi with the governor every Friday. A wit has remarked that in a year’s time, he will surely be President of the Court! Indeed, nothing seems impossible under this system. Appointments are made without scrutiny; the minister is deceived into believing that no qualified candidates exist within the colony, and thus the governor's cronies must be appointed. However, we shall cite <tei-persName ref="#Mo" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Mosse</tei-persName>, a lawyer of the colony, who for nearly ten years has frequently been called upon to sit as a judge whenever the court was incomplete. He is the most senior lawyer on the registry, and he is highly learned. Yet, strangely enough, he has been entirely overlooked—for the simple reason that he is not part of the coterie.”<tei-pb facs="v1n5f36" n="37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">We trust that M. the Minister <tei-persName ref="#JAC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jacob</tei-persName> will reject such intrigues and that he will appoint, to the critical position of President of the Court, an impartial metropolitan magistrate—one independent of colonial cliques, whose conduct will embody the integrity and justice that distinguished <tei-persName ref="#PERS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. Persegol</tei-persName>.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">P.S.—M. Parizet, who has been in office but three months, has already restored men of color to their rightful places on the list of assessors. Furthermore, he has just secured a scholarship in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName> for a child of color. No commentary is needed; compare his brief tenure with the five years of M. Jubelin.</tei-p></tei-q>
</tei-div>
<tei-div xml:id="foreign-colonies" id="foreign-colonies" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#JA" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">JAMAICA</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Order and tranquility continue to prevail in the colony; however, frequent disputes arise between the planters and the newly apprenticed laborers. It appears that these misunderstandings stem largely from the proclamation issued by the Governor-General, <tei-persName ref="#Sligo" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">the Marquis of Sligo</tei-persName>, which led the apprentices to believe that every Friday, half the day was rightfully their own. In several districts, the planters had reached an agreement among themselves to establish uniform working hours.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The city of <tei-placeName ref="#K" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Kingston</tei-placeName> experienced, on the night of September 7, <tei-pb facs="v1n5f37" n="38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> a rather severe earthquake. For several days prior, the heat had been excessive, and the thermometer had risen considerably. At half past two in the morning, the ground began to undulate slightly; the first tremors were weak and seemed to diminish gradually. However, all at once, a violent shock was felt. This terrifying phenomenon lasted for half a minute. The city suffered little damage.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="antigua" id="antigua" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#ANT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ANTIGUA</tei-placeName>.</tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">In one of the chapels of this island, religious services commenced on the evening of July 31, at nine o’clock. Sermons and hymns followed one another until nearly midnight. A few minutes before that solemn hour, the minister invited the Christian slaves to kneel and, in silent prayer, to receive as if from the hand of God Himself the blessing of liberty, which the next instant would place in their possession. All fell upon their knees, their hands and hearts raised toward Heaven; on all sides, suppressed sobs could be heard, which they strove in vain to restrain. It became impossible to hold them back when the bell tolled: each of its twelve strokes heightened their emotion. The minister then announced a hymn to keep their minds fixed upon the holy thoughts that had occupied them until that moment; and when it had been sung, the congregation dispersed slowly.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">All the chapels in Antigua were full. Nowhere on the island was there quarreling, nor revelry, nor any form of excess. The harmony reigning between the planters and their former slaves will powerfully aid, under the guiding hand of Christian conviction, in rendering easy the immense transformation introduced into the social order.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="saint-lucia" id="saint-lucia" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT LUCIA</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">We receive word from <tei-placeName ref="#Cas" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Castries</tei-placeName>:</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">On August 1, the proclamation and enforcement of the Emancipation Bill took place on this island. In honor of this great act of regeneration, a grand mass was celebrated in the parish church. The governor attended, accompanied by a detachment of 23 soldiers and the military band—the only force necessary to effect so profound a transformation in the social order of this colony. <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Hurrahs</tei-emph> and <tei-emph data-origname="emph">vivats</tei-emph> <tei-pb facs="v1n5f38" n="39" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> bore witness to the joy of the free population and the newly emancipated. The day passed in the utmost tranquility; not a single disturbance occurred. That evening, the town was illuminated.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div xml:id="bibliography" id="bibliography" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
<tei-head data-origname="head">BIBLIOGRAPHY.</tei-head>
<tei-head data-origname="head">TRIAL OF THE GRAND'ANSE (MARTINIQUE).</tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Memoir</tei-emph> on behalf of the ninety-three condemned, submitted to the Court of Cassation, before which their appeal is now pending, by <tei-persName ref="#Gatine" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">M. AD. GATINE</tei-persName>, advocate at the Court of Cassation. <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>, printed by Dezauche, 14, rue du Faubourg-Montmartre.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-quote data-origname="quote">Unfortunate <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>! Land consecrated to suffering! In <tei-date data-origname="date">1831</tei-date>, TWENTY-SIX <tei-emph data-origname="emph">conspirators</tei-emph> hanged in a single day! Today, FORTY-ONE condemned to death in a single day <tei-emph data-origname="emph">for conspiracy</tei-emph>! Colonists, <tei-choice data-origname="choice">
   <tei-orig data-origname="orig">imprudens</tei-orig>
   <tei-reg data-origname="reg">imprudent</tei-reg>
</tei-choice> 
as much as inhumane, you dishonor the scaffold. (Page 25.)</tei-quote></tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Such is the epigraph of the excellent preparatory <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Memoir</tei-emph> composed by M. Gatine for the condemned of Grand'Anse. This dreadful affair is therein illuminated with such historical clarity that none but the most hardened apologist of colonial privilege could fail to recognize the innocence of the so-called conspirators. It is impossible, after reading M. Gatine’s <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Memoir</tei-emph>, not to be overwhelmed with indignation and scorn for the wretched policy of that handful of Machiavellian oppressors for whom atrocity seems to be a principle of public law. No, not a single one of our brethren shall suffer the punishment to which he has been condemned—despite the presence in Paris of two of their most implacable enemies. We do not call them judges: men of color have no judges in Martinique.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">M. Gatine casts broad and brilliant light upon this supposed conspiracy, to the everlasting shame of the white aristocracy of that island! "We write for history, even as we write in defense of the condemned," M. Gatine declares at the outset; "for such a trial is an immense social fact, which shall not pass unremarked in the annals of a people. We shall maintain the solemnity befitting profound sorrow, the moderation that is not incompatible with a keen and righteous resentment for so many sacrifices—but also the firmness demanded in this, the posthumous defense of so many men condemned to <tei-pb facs="v1n5f39" n="40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n facs" data-empty=""/> perish upon the scaffold, in the galleys, or in exile; and of whom several, already dead in prison, shall never witness the final outcome of this trial."</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">We shall not follow M. Gatine through his lucid exposition of the facts; nor shall we recount again the history of this affair, already well known to our readers. We shall confine ourselves to expressing our deepest gratitude to this worthy advocate for the fervent eloquence with which he has undertaken the defense of men and causes so dear to us in every way. Honor to M. Gatine! He has well understood the mission of this age! Justice and equality for all—this is the first need, the first cry of the nations of our day.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">Oppression cannot long endure in Martinique, organized as it is at present. More, perhaps, than anywhere else on the globe, it is exercised against the disinherited races with an incredible contempt for right and reason; but such a state of affairs is itself the herald of its own impending fall. The colonial aristocracy nears its final hour; for to survive, it must take more heads than the world will allow it to sever, and spill more blood than it has the power to shed.</tei-p>

<tei-p data-origname="p">In an upcoming memoir, M. Gatine will present the grounds for cassation, which are numerous and give every reason to expect the fair admission of the appeal. The judgment of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">these self-appointed judges and executioners</tei-emph> shall be overturned by metropolitan justice. But when, at last, shall there be a judiciary to protect the colonies?</tei-p>
</tei-div>
